Class XmlTransaction

The handle for a transaction, encapsulating a Berkeley DbTxn object. Methods of the XmlTransaction class are used to abort and commit the transaction. XmlTransaction handles are provided to Container, XmlManager, and other objects that query and modify documents and containers in order to transactionally protect those database operations.

Namespace: Figaro
Assembly: Figaro.dll
Syntax
public sealed class XmlTransaction : IDisposable
Remarks

XmlTransaction objects are instantiated using CreateTransaction().

XmlTransaction handles are not free-threaded; transactions handles may be used by multiple threads, but only serially, that is, the application must serialize access to the XmlTransaction handle. Once the Abort() or Commit() methods are called, the handle may not be accessed again, regardless of the method's return. In addition, parent transactions may not issue any operations while they have active child transactions (child transactions that have not yet been committed or aborted) except for Abort() and Commit().

If the object is used after a commit or abort, an exception is thrown.

Methods

View Source

Abort()

Causes an abnormal termination of the transaction. All write operations previously performed within the scope of the transaction are undone. Before this method returns, any locks held by the transaction will have been released.

Declaration
public void Abort()
View Source

Commit()

Ends the transaction.

Declaration
public void Commit()
Remarks

Container and document modifications made within the scope of the transaction are by default written to stable storage.

After Commit() has been called, regardless of its return, the XmlTransaction handle may not be accessed again. If Commit() encounters an error, the transaction and all child transactions of the transaction are aborted.

The Commit() method throws an exception that encapsulates a non-zero error value on failure.

View Source

Commit(Boolean)

Ends the transaction.

Declaration
public void Commit(bool sync)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Boolean sync

If true, synchronously flushes the log. If false, the log will not synchronously flush.

Using this method will override any synchronization property set at XmlTransaction creation.

Remarks

Container and document modifications made within the scope of the transaction are by default written to stable storage.

After Commit() has been called, regardless of its return, the XmlTransaction handle may not be accessed again. If Commit() encounters an error, the transaction and all child transactions of the transaction are aborted.

The Commit() method throws an exception that encapsulates a non-zero error value on failure.

XmlTransaction

The child transaction.
Remarks

While this child transaction is active (has been neither committed nor aborted), the parent transaction may not issue any operations except for Commit() or Abort().
